title: M4: Reducer plus checkpoints v0.1
description:
Implement the pure reducer function (State, Event) -> State with checkpoint support, state_hash computation, and determinism verification. The reducer rebuilds application state from the EventLog — it is the bridge between raw truth and usable data.

KEY INVARIANTS: I2 (deterministic projection — State is input to projection), I4 (testable determinism — state_hash stability).
CONSTITUTION: CAPACITY_ENVELOPE (checkpoint interval = 5000 events).
FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/reducer.rs plus tests.

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Pure function reduce(state, event) -> State: no IO, no randomness, no wall clock
- Checkpoint every 5000 events, versioned format with reducer_version and commit_index
- Rebuild from checkpoint + replay equals full replay
- state_hash = BLAKE3(reducer_version + canonical_serialize(State)), with explicit include/exclude list
- Determinism test: same EventLog yields same state_hash across 10 repeated runs

DEPENDS ON: M2 (append writer — for reading EventLogs with CommittedEvents). BLOCKS: M5 (projection).
close_reason: M4 complete: Pure reducer (State, CommittedEvent) -> State for all 9 payload variants. BTreeMap-only State (no HashMap). Checkpoint every 5000 events with versioned format. state_hash = BLAKE3(reducer_version + canonical State). Determinism verified: 10-run tests pass. 33 tests total. Quality gates: fmt ✓, clippy ✓, 108 tests ✓. UBS: 1 critical fixed (f64 quantization), 6 warnings noted. Risk assessment appended.

comments.author: yuan-cloud
comments.text: DEPENDENCY CHANGE: M4 now depends on M1 (not M2). The reducer processes CommittedEvents but can construct them directly for testing — it only needs the event TYPE definitions from M1, not the append writer implementation from M2. This unlocks M4 to start in parallel with M2 after M1 completes. Three parallel tracks after M1: M2 (writer), M3 (parser), and M4 (reducer).

title: M4.1: State struct definition
description:
Define the State struct that the reducer produces — the accumulated knowledge from replaying the EventLog.

DESIGN REQUIREMENTS:
- All map-like containers MUST be BTreeMap (not HashMap) for deterministic serialization and hashing
- No floats without explicit quantization
- Must implement Serialize, Deserialize (for checkpointing)
- Must implement Clone, PartialEq, Eq
- Must be hashable via custom state_hash function (M4.4)

MINIMUM STATE FIELDS:
- run_metadata: BTreeMap<String, RunInfo> — per-run metadata
- event_counts_by_type: BTreeMap<String, u64> — counts by event type
- event_counts_by_tier: BTreeMap<Tier, u64> — counts by tier
- tool_summaries: BTreeMap<String, ToolSummary> — tool call/result aggregation
- policy_decisions: Vec<PolicyTransition> — recorded ladder transitions (ordered by commit_index)
- error_log: Vec<ErrorEntry> — accumulated errors (ordered)
- clock_skew_events: Vec<ClockSkewEntry> — recorded skew detections
- redaction_log: Vec<RedactionEntry> — recorded redactions
- last_commit_index: u64 — highest commit_index processed
- tier_a_count: u64, tier_a_drops: u64 (drops should always be 0)

DESIGN NOTES:
- State must contain enough for Projection (M5) to build complete ViewModel with all confession fields
- State must NOT contain rendering/UI concerns (that's Projection's job)
- State is truth-derived — always rebuildable from EventLog
- Keep it flat where possible (deep nesting makes determinism auditing harder)
- reducer_version is a constant on the module, not a State field (it's included in hash computation separately)

INVARIANTS: I2 (deterministic projection — State is projection input).
FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/reducer.rs
close_reason: State struct with 11 fields, all BTreeMap (no HashMap), Serialize/Deserialize/Clone/PartialEq/Eq. Supporting structs: RunInfo, ToolSummary, PolicyTransition, ErrorEntry, ClockSkewEntry, RedactionEntry.

title: M4.2: Pure reduce function for all Tier A events
description:
Implement the pure reducer function for all Tier A event variants.

SIGNATURE: fn reduce(state: &State, event: &CommittedEvent) -> State

PURITY CONTRACT:
- No IO (no file reads, network, stdin)
- No randomness (no rand, thread_rng)
- No wall clock (no SystemTime::now, Instant::now)
- No interior mutability that could leak nondeterminism
- Same inputs → always same output

HANDLING PER TIER A VARIANT:
1. RunStart → add run metadata to state.run_metadata
2. RunEnd → update run status to completed
3. ToolCall → increment tool call count, add to tool_summaries
4. ToolResult → update tool result status in summaries
5. PolicyDecision → record transition in state.policy_decisions
6. RedactionApplied → record in state.redaction_log
7. Error → record in state.error_log
8. ClockSkewDetected → record in state.clock_skew_events
9. Generic → increment generic event count by type

IMPORTANT: The synthesized flag is metadata. Reducer processes synthesized events identically to non-synthesized (PLANS.md).

INVARIANTS: I2 (deterministic projection), I1 (forensic truth — reducer reflects truth).
FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/reducer.rs
close_reason: Pure reduce(state, event) -> State for all 9 variants. f64 queue_pressure quantized to u64 millionths with clamp+round. Synthesized events treated identically. 14 unit tests.

title: M4.3: Checkpoint serialization and interval-based checkpointing
description:
Implement checkpoint serialization and interval-based checkpointing.

CHECKPOINT SEMANTICS:
- Every N events (N=5000 from CAPACITY_ENVELOPE), save current State
- Checkpoint includes: reducer_version, commit_index of last event reduced, serialized State
- Format is versioned so future reducer changes don't corrupt old checkpoints

USAGE:
- On startup with checkpoint: load it, replay only events after checkpoint's commit_index
- Much faster restart for large EventLogs (skip replaying first N events)
- Rebuild from checkpoint + replay must produce identical state as full replay (M4.5 test)

STORAGE:
- Single JSON file alongside EventLog
- Filename includes checkpoint commit_index (e.g., checkpoint-4999.json)
- Checkpoints are derived artifacts — deletable, always rebuildable

ERROR HANDLING:
- Corrupt checkpoint → fall back to full replay (log warning)
- Version mismatch (checkpoint reducer_version != current) → full replay
- Never trust a checkpoint blindly — validate reducer_version

CONSTITUTION: CAPACITY_ENVELOPE (Checkpoint interval events = 5000).
FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/reducer.rs
close_reason: Checkpoint struct with reducer_version + commit_index + State. create/serialize/load_checkpoint functions. Version mismatch returns None. Interval at 5000 events.

title: M4.4: state_hash computation (BLAKE3)
description:
Implement state_hash computation using BLAKE3.

FORMULA: state_hash = BLAKE3(reducer_version_bytes + canonical_serialize(State))

IMPLEMENTATION:
1. Create BLAKE3 hasher
2. Feed reducer_version bytes (e.g., b"reducer-v0.1")
3. Feed deterministically serialized State bytes
4. Finalize to hash
5. Return as lowercase hex string

DOCUMENTATION REQUIREMENTS (near hashing code):
- Explicit INCLUDE list: all State fields that affect replay correctness
- Explicit EXCLUDE list: any transient/cached fields (if any exist)
- Note: reducer_version changes when reducer logic changes, producing visibly different hashes

WHY reducer_version IN HASH: If we change how the reducer processes events (e.g., count differently), the state_hash must change even if the EventLog is the same. Including reducer_version ensures this.

USED FOR: determinism verification, checkpoint validation, CI assertions, timetravel.capture seek points.

INVARIANTS: I4 (testable determinism).
FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/reducer.rs
close_reason: state_hash = BLAKE3(reducer_version + canonical_serialize(State)). 64-char hex. Include/exclude list documented. 4 tests including version sensitivity.

title: M4.5: Checkpoint rebuild equivalence test
description:
Test: checkpoint + remaining replay produces same state as full replay.

PROTOCOL:
1. Create EventLog with N > 5000 events (e.g., 6000 events)
2. Full replay: reduce all N events from scratch → state_full
3. Checkpoint replay: reduce first 5000 → save checkpoint → load checkpoint → reduce remaining → state_checkpoint
4. Assert state_full == state_checkpoint
5. Assert state_hash(state_full) == state_hash(state_checkpoint)

ADDITIONAL: verify at multiple boundaries:
- Checkpoint at exactly 5000 (interval boundary)
- Checkpoint at 10000 (2× interval)
- Checkpoint at 5001 (interval + 1)

This test validates: checkpoint serialization is lossless, State deserialization is deterministic, reducer produces consistent state regardless of start point.

FILES: crates/vifei-core/tests/
close_reason: Checkpoint rebuild equivalence verified at 4 boundaries: 6000 events (mixed types), exact 5000, 5001, 10001. state == state_checkpoint and state_hash matches in all cases.

title: M4.6: Reducer determinism test (10 runs)
description:
Test: same EventLog yields same state_hash across 10 repeated runs.

PROTOCOL:
1. Create a fixed EventLog (deterministic fixture)
2. Loop 10 times: full replay from scratch → compute state_hash → store
3. Assert all 10 hashes are identical

WHY 10 RUNS: HashMap nondeterminism is probabilistic. A single run might coincidentally produce the same order. 10 runs makes false-pass probability negligible.

CATCHES:
- Hidden HashMap iteration nondeterminism
- Thread-local state leaks
- Floating point accumulation order differences
- Any subtle nondeterminism in the reducer

IF FLAKY: A flaky result here indicates a REAL determinism bug, not a test issue. Investigate immediately — check for HashMap, random seeds, time dependencies.

INVARIANTS: I4 (testable determinism), I2 (deterministic projection).
FILES: crates/vifei-core/tests/
close_reason: Determinism 10-run test: 100 diverse events (all 9 variants) x10 runs, all hashes identical. Plus 5500-event large test x10 runs crossing checkpoint boundary.

title: TRACK-E: robot-mode intent-repair vs fail-closed execution contract hardening
description: Background: recent incident-pack work exposed a runtime serialization fallback that could silently mask artifact regressions, while robot-mode also intentionally permits narrow input normalization repairs. Goal: codify and enforce the boundary between (A) allowed intent-repair at parse boundary and (B) mandatory fail-closed behavior for runtime/artifact integrity paths. Scope includes policy docs, targeted code hardening, and regression tests. Non-goals: broad refactors, changing constitutional semantics, or removing supported repair allowlist behavior.
close_reason: TRACK-E complete: audit, contract tests, runtime fallback hardening, policy codification, guardrail test, and closeout evidence all landed

comments.author: yuan-cloud
comments.text:
Execution intent for TRACK-E

Why this exists:
- We intentionally support parser-level repair notes for unambiguous syntax variants.
- We do not allow runtime/artifact correctness fallbacks that can hide regressions.
- Recent work surfaced one such masking bug and one adjacent potential risk.

Success criteria:
1) Policy boundary is explicit in docs and tests.
2) Runtime masking fallbacks are eliminated or formally justified.
3) CI has at least one guard against reintroducing this class.
4) Contract behavior remains stable for both robot and human modes.

Out of scope:
- Any broad CLI redesign.
- Any change to constitutional semantics.
- Any change to allowed normalization list unless justified by ambiguity analysis.

Proof artifacts expected at closeout:
- audit table with classification and file:line proof
- test evidence showing repaired-input success path unchanged
- test evidence showing runtime fault path fails closed with structured envelope

- Changed dependency so runtime hardening (bd-2cj9.3) now depends on test hardening (bd-2cj9.2), not the reverse.
- Rationale: define and lock behavioral contract before mutation; reduces regression risk and supports red/green workflow.

No cycles introduced; dependency graph remains acyclic.

title: M5.1: ProjectionInvariants and LadderLevel
description:
Define the ProjectionInvariants struct that parameterizes the projection function.

FIELDS:
- version: String — "projection-invariants-v0.1" (from BACKPRESSURE_POLICY § Versioning)
- degradation_level: LadderLevel — current position on degradation ladder

LadderLevel ENUM:
- L0Normal, L1Aggregate, L2Collapse, L3ReduceFidelity, L4FreezeUI, L5SafeFailure
- Traits: Display, FromStr, Serialize, Deserialize, Clone, Copy, PartialEq, Eq, PartialOrd, Ord
- Ord ordering: L0 < L1 < L2 < L3 < L4 < L5 (for transition direction comparisons)
- Display: "L0", "L1", etc. (matches BACKPRESSURE_POLICY ladder level identifiers)

VERSION CONTRACT:
- Version changes when any projection invariant rule is added/removed/modified (BACKPRESSURE_POLICY)
- Version changes when ViewModel include/exclude list for hashing changes
- Embedded in ViewModel, metrics.json, and timetravel.capture

DESIGN NOTE: ProjectionInvariants is NOT part of State (reducer output). It is a separate input to the projection function. This keeps the reducer pure and the projection independently configurable.

CONSTITUTION: BACKPRESSURE_POLICY (projection invariants v0.1, ladder levels).

Define the ViewModel struct — the hashable data structure that drives the TUI.

- tier_a_summaries: BTreeMap<String, u64> — Tier A events by type
- aggregation_mode: String — e.g., "1:1", "10:1", "collapsed"
- aggregation_bin_size: Option<u64> — bin size when aggregating
- degradation_level: LadderLevel — current ladder level
- queue_pressure: f64 — normalized ratio [0.0, 1.0] (display only in v0.1; format with explicit precision for determinism)
- tier_a_drops: u64 — must be 0 in normal operation
- export_safety_state: ExportSafetyState — Unknown (default until M8), Clean, Dirty, Refused
- projection_invariants_version: String

ExportSafetyState ENUM: Unknown, Clean, Dirty, Refused (with Display, serde)

EXPLICITLY EXCLUDED (MUST NOT appear in ViewModel):
- Terminal size / window dimensions
- Focus state (which pane is focused)
- Cursor blink state
- Wall clock / current time
- Random values

DETERMINISM RULES:
- All map-like fields use BTreeMap (not HashMap)
- queue_pressure: f64 must have explicit formatting when serialized for hashing (e.g., format!("{:.6}", qp))
- Must implement Serialize for hashing
- ViewModel is a snapshot at a specific point in time

ExportSafetyState enum (Unknown/Clean/Dirty/Refused). BTreeMap-only, quantized f64 for determinism. 20 new tests.

title: M5.3: Deterministic project() function
description:
Implement the deterministic projection function.

SIGNATURE: fn project(state: &State, invariants: &ProjectionInvariants) -> ViewModel

PURITY CONTRACT: No IO, no randomness, no wall clock. Same inputs → same output.

BEHAVIOR BY LADDER LEVEL:
- L0 (Normal): 1:1 events rendered, full detail in summaries
- L1 (Aggregate): Bin Tier B/C events, Tier A remains 1:1
- L2 (Collapse): Collapse Tier B/C into counts/histograms, Tier A 1:1
- L3 (Reduce Fidelity): Simplified rendering, fewer redraws, Tier A 1:1
- L4 (Freeze UI): Non-HUD panes frozen, Truth HUD confession fields remain live from ingest state
- L5 (Safe Failure): Minimal — show failure state

PROJECTION INVARIANT RULES (BACKPRESSURE_POLICY):
- NEVER fabricate events
- NEVER reorder truth
- Iterate by commit_index, NEVER by timestamp
- May summarize Tier B/C per ladder, MUST confess in Truth HUD
- MUST visually distinguish synthesized fields (events with synthesized: true)
- Truth HUD must confess: ladder level, aggregation, queue pressure, drops, export state, version

IMPLEMENTATION:
- Walk state fields, build ViewModel
- Apply degradation rules based on invariants.degradation_level
- Compute all confession fields from state
- Return ViewModel

FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/projection.rs
close_reason: M5.3 complete: Deterministic project(State, ProjectionInvariants) -> ViewModel. Pure function (no IO, no randomness, no wall clock). Ladder-level aggregation modes (1:1, 10:1, collapsed, frozen). Extracts Tier A summaries, queue pressure from policy decisions. 13 new tests including determinism and byte-stability.

title: M5.4: viewmodel.hash computation (BLAKE3)
description:
Implement viewmodel.hash computation.

FORMULA: viewmodel.hash = BLAKE3(canonical_serialize(ViewModel))

IMPLEMENTATION:
1. Serialize ViewModel deterministically (serde_json::to_vec or custom canonical form)
2. Feed bytes to BLAKE3 hasher
3. Return lowercase hex string
4. For file output: single line, newline-terminated

DOCUMENTATION (near hashing code):
- INCLUDE list: all ViewModel fields (all confession fields)
- EXCLUDE list: nothing in v0.1 (all fields are meaningful)
- Note: projection_invariants_version is part of ViewModel and therefore part of hash input
- Note: queue_pressure (f64) must serialize with explicit precision to avoid platform-dependent formatting

FLOAT HANDLING: queue_pressure is f64. For hash stability:
- Quantize to fixed decimal places (e.g., 6 decimal places)
- Or multiply by 1,000,000 and store as u64
- Document the choice and lock with a test

USED BY: Tour (M7) viewmodel.hash artifact, CI hash stability assertions, timetravel.capture seek points.
INVARIANTS: I4 (testable determinism).
FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/projection.rs

title: M5.5: viewmodel.hash stability test (10 runs)
description:
Test: same EventLog + same ProjectionInvariants → same viewmodel.hash across 10 runs.

PROTOCOL:
1. Create fixed EventLog (deterministic fixture)
2. Create fixed ProjectionInvariants (version = "projection-invariants-v0.1", degradation_level = L0)
3. Loop 10 times: full reduce → project → compute viewmodel.hash → store
4. Assert all 10 hashes identical

This is the projection-layer analog of M4.6 (reducer determinism test). Together they prove the full pipeline: EventLog → reduce → project → hash is deterministic.

CATCHES: HashMap in ViewModel (shouldn't exist but catches regressions), float formatting instability, any nondeterminism introduced by the projection function.

IF FLAKY: Real bug. Check for HashMap, unsorted containers, float formatting, time dependencies in ViewModel.

INVARIANTS: I4 (testable determinism), I2 (deterministic projection).

title: M1: Event schema v0.1
description:
Define all D2 Tier A event types with deterministic serde, commit_index ownership enforcement, and byte-stable round-trip serialization. This is the foundation type system that every downstream bead builds upon.

KEY INVARIANTS: I1 (forensic truth — EventLog structure), I4 (testable determinism — byte stability).
CONSTITUTION: D2 (Tier A minimal set), D6 (canonical ordering model).
FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/event.rs plus unit tests.

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Defines all D2 Tier A events (RunStart, RunEnd, ToolCall, ToolResult, PolicyDecision, RedactionApplied, Error, ClockSkewDetected)
- Event struct includes: run_id, event_id, source_id, source_seq, timestamp_ns, commit_index, tier, payload_ref, synthesized
- commit_index represented so importers cannot set it (two-type pattern recommended: ImportEvent vs CommittedEvent)
- Round-trip serialize→deserialize→re-serialize yields identical bytes for every Tier A variant
- Tier enum supports A/B/C with Display, FromStr, serde-as-string
- Generic extensible variant for future Tier B/C events
- Module docs explain byte stability strategy and commit_index ownership rationale

DEPENDS ON: M0 (workspace scaffold, closed). BLOCKS: M2, and transitively M3/M4/M5/M6/M7/M8.
close_reason: M1 complete: all 6 subtasks closed. Event schema v0.1 with two-type pattern, 8 Tier A variants, Generic extensible, deterministic serde, 32 round-trip tests. Risk assessment appended.

title: M1.1: Tier enum (A/B/C) with Display, FromStr, serde
description:
Implement the Tier enum with three variants: A, B, C.

REQUIRED TRAITS:
- Display: renders as "A", "B", "C"
- FromStr: parses case-insensitively
- Serialize/Deserialize: JSON representation is string "A"/"B"/"C" (not integer)
- PartialOrd/Ord: A > B > C for priority comparisons

BACKGROUND: Tiers classify event importance for backpressure. Tier A is never dropped, never reordered (BACKPRESSURE_POLICY). Tier B may be sampled under load. Tier C is best-effort. The enum is used in every event and in backpressure ladder decisions.

IMPLEMENTATION NOTES:
- Use serde rename or custom impl to ensure JSON is "A" not "0"
- Display and FromStr must be consistent with serde representation
- Consider #[derive(Clone, Copy, PartialEq, Eq, Hash)] for ergonomics
- This is a small but foundational type — get it right and everything downstream works

ACCEPTANCE TEST: Tier::A serializes to "A", round-trips identically, parses from "A"/"a".

FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/event.rs
close_reason: Tier enum implemented with Display, FromStr, serde (string), Ord (A>B>C). All tests pass.

title: M1.2: Event type hierarchy with commit_index ownership
description:
Design and implement the event type hierarchy that enforces commit_index ownership at the type system level.

THE CORE CONSTRAINT (D6): The append writer is the sole assigner of commit_index. Importers must never set it.

RECOMMENDED APPROACH (from PLANS.md): Two-type pattern:
- ImportEvent: struct with all event fields EXCEPT commit_index. This is what importers produce.
- CommittedEvent: wraps ImportEvent plus commit_index: u64. Only the append writer creates these.
- This makes the constraint a compile-time error — importers literally cannot set a field that doesn't exist.

ALTERNATIVE: Option<u64> pattern where importers leave commit_index as None. Weaker because it's a runtime check, not compile-time. If chosen, must add immediate runtime validation.

COMMON FIELDS (both types):
- run_id: String (identity of a run)
- event_id: String (unique within run_id)
- source_id: String (identifies the source/importer)
- source_seq: Option<u64> (monotonic per source when available)
- timestamp_ns: u64 (metadata only, NEVER for ordering — D6)
- tier: Tier
- payload_ref: Option<String> (BLAKE3 hex when payload is blobbed)
- synthesized: bool (default false — D2 rule: mark inferred fields)

CommittedEvent additionally has:
- commit_index: u64 (assigned by append writer only)

WHY THIS MATTERS: This decision is load-bearing for M2 (append writer), M3 (importer), M4 (reducer), and all downstream beads. The M1 handoff must document which approach was chosen and why.

INVARIANTS: I1 (forensic truth), D6 (canonical ordering).
FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/event.rs
close_reason: Two-type pattern: ImportEvent (no commit_index) + CommittedEvent (commit_index via ::commit()). D6 enforced at compile time.

title: M1.3: Tier A event payload variants
description:
Define all D2 Tier A event payload variants as an enum. Each variant carries typed fields appropriate to its semantics.

D2 TIER A EVENTS (from PLANS.md):
1. RunStart — beginning of agent run. Fields: run metadata, agent identifier, start context.
2. RunEnd — end of run. Fields: exit status, summary, final metrics.
3. ToolCall — agent invokes a tool. Fields: tool name, arguments (potentially large → payload_ref). Arguments may exceed inline threshold (16,384 bytes from CAPACITY_ENVELOPE).
4. ToolResult — tool returns a result. Fields: tool name, result (potentially large → payload_ref), status code.
5. PolicyDecision — backpressure/policy decision made. Fields: from_level, to_level, trigger, queue_pressure. CRITICAL: Tour CI assertions (M7) cross-reference these with metrics.json degradation_transitions.
6. RedactionApplied — redaction applied to event/field. Fields: target event_id, field_path, reason.
7. Error — an error occurred. Fields: error kind, message, severity.
8. ClockSkewDetected — timestamp moved backward beyond tolerance. Fields: source_id, expected_ns, actual_ns, delta_ns.

EXTENSIBILITY: Include a Generic variant for future Tier B/C events:
- Generic { tier: Tier, event_type: String, ... }
- Prevents schema-breaking changes when new types are added
- Data field must NOT be serde_json::Value on disk — use payload_ref for large/dynamic data, or a BTreeMap<String, String> for small structured data

DESIGN NOTES:
- ToolCall/ToolResult arguments may be huge (full LLM responses). These MUST support payload_ref blobbing.
- PolicyDecision must include enough context (from_level, to_level, trigger, queue_pressure) for M7 CI assertions.
- The synthesized flag lives on the event wrapper (ImportEvent/CommittedEvent), not per-variant.
- Do not invent meaning: D2 rule says mark synthesized fields explicitly.

FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/event.rs
close_reason: All 8 Tier A payload variants + Generic extensible variant defined. BTreeMap for Generic data, f64 for queue_pressure with Ryu determinism.

title: M1.4: Canonical serde audit and configuration
description:
Audit and configure canonical serde for all event types defined in M1.2-M1.3.

CONTEXT: When M1.2 and M1.3 define event types, they use #[derive(Serialize, Deserialize)] and choose container types (BTreeMap, etc.). This bead is the VERIFICATION and CONFIGURATION step that ensures all serde decisions are correct for determinism.

THIS BEAD IS NOT about "adding serde" (that's done via derive in M1.2-M1.3). It's about:

1. AUDIT: Verify no HashMap or serde_json::Value in any serialized path
   - Run: rg 'HashMap' -t rust crates/vifei-core/src/event.rs
   - Run: rg 'serde_json::Value' -t rust crates/vifei-core/src/event.rs
   - Any hits are bugs that must be fixed

2. CONFIGURE custom serde behavior where derive defaults are insufficient:
   - Tier enum: verify serde serializes as "A"/"B"/"C" strings, not integers
   - Generic variant data field: configure serialization strategy (BTreeMap<String,String> or payload_ref)
   - Any optional fields: verify None serializes correctly (omitted or null — pick one, document as canonical)
   - Newtype wrappers (if used): verify transparent serialization

3. DOCUMENT the canonical contract:
   - Add inline comment listing field order as it appears in serialized JSON
   - Note which fields are optional and how they serialize when absent
   - Note which container types are used and why

4. ADD serde-specific tests (distinct from round-trip tests in M1.5):
   - Verify field order in output matches struct declaration order
   - Verify BTreeMap keys appear sorted in output
   - Verify no unintended fields appear in output

DETERMINISM REQUIREMENTS (PLANS.md):
- One JSON object per line, newline-terminated
- No pretty printing, no embedded newlines
- UTF-8 bytes, field order = struct declaration order
- No HashMap, no serde_json::Value in serialized paths

FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/event.rs
close_reason: Serde audit complete: no HashMap, no serde_json::Value, field order verified, skip_serializing_if for optionals, BTreeMap sorted keys verified.

comments.author: yuan-cloud
comments.text: CLARIFICATION: This bead was redefined from 'implement serde' to 'audit serde.' Serde is implemented via #[derive(Serialize, Deserialize)] in M1.2-M1.3 when types are defined. This bead verifies the derive-based serde meets determinism requirements and adds any custom configuration needed.

title: M1.5: Round-trip byte stability tests
description:
Write comprehensive round-trip tests proving byte stability of event serialization.

TEST PROTOCOL for each case:
1. Construct an Event programmatically
2. Serialize to JSON string (serde_json::to_string)
3. Deserialize back to Event (serde_json::from_str)
4. Re-serialize to JSON string
5. Assert bytes from step 2 == bytes from step 4

REQUIRED COVERAGE (from PLANS.md M1 acceptance criteria):
- All 8 Tier A variants: RunStart, RunEnd, ToolCall, ToolResult, PolicyDecision, RedactionApplied, Error, ClockSkewDetected
- Event with payload_ref set (simulates blobbed payload)
- Event with synthesized: true
- Event with source_seq absent (None)
- Generic event variant (Tier B/C placeholder)

EDGE CASES:
- Empty string fields (must be stable)
- Unicode in payload/tool names (UTF-8 encoding stability)
- Very long field values (within inline threshold)
- Numeric precision: u64 max values for timestamp_ns
- BTreeMap fields: verify sorted output

WHY THIS MATTERS: This test is the primary defense against accidental determinism regressions. If a future change breaks byte stability, this test catches it immediately. It directly enforces I4 (testable determinism).

FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/event.rs (#[cfg(test)]) or crates/vifei-core/tests/
close_reason: 32 round-trip tests: all 8 Tier A variants, payload_ref, synthesized:true, source_seq:None, Generic, empty strings, unicode, u64::MAX, float determinism.

title: M1.6: Event module documentation
description:
Write module-level Rust doc comments for event.rs making it self-documenting.

1. Overview of event type hierarchy (ImportEvent vs CommittedEvent or chosen approach)

This documentation is explicitly required by PLANS.md M1 acceptance criteria and is critical for future agents working on downstream beads.

title: M2: Append writer v0.1
description:
Implement the single append writer (sole assigner of commit_index), content-addressed blob store (BLAKE3), and clock skew detection. This is the write-path infrastructure that all data flows through.

KEY INVARIANTS: I1 (forensic truth — EventLog is canonical), I5 (loud failure — FM-APPEND-FAIL, FM-BLOB-WRITE-FAIL).
CONSTITUTION: CAPACITY_ENVELOPE (fsync interval, inline threshold, max blob bytes, stall alarm, clock skew tolerance), BACKPRESSURE_POLICY (FM-APPEND-FAIL, FM-BLOB-WRITE-FAIL).
FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/eventlog.rs, crates/vifei-core/src/blob_store.rs plus tests.

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Single writer appends events to JSONL with monotonically increasing commit_index (starts at 0, increments by 1)
- commit_index assigned in exactly one code path (the append writer)
- Content-addressed blob store: payloads above 16,384 bytes stored as blobs, payload_ref is lowercase hex BLAKE3 digest
- ClockSkewDetected emitted when source timestamp_ns moves backward > 50ms tolerance
- Tests: 1000-event monotonicity, blob creation + resolution, backward timestamp detection

DEPENDS ON: M1 (event types). BLOCKS: M3 (importer), M4 (reducer), M8 (export).
close_reason: M2 complete: all 6 subtasks closed. Append writer (sole commit_index assigner), BLAKE3 blob store, clock skew detection. 20 tests, risk assessment appended.

title: M2.1: JSONL append writer with monotonic commit_index
description:
Implement the single append writer — the sole code path for writing events to the EventLog JSONL file and assigning commit_index.

CORE BEHAVIOR:
- Opens or creates a JSONL file at a specified path
- Accepts ImportEvent values (no commit_index)
- Assigns commit_index: starts at 0 for new files, increments by exactly 1
- Converts ImportEvent → CommittedEvent by wrapping with assigned commit_index
- Serializes CommittedEvent to canonical JSON (one line, newline-terminated)
- Appends the line to the JSONL file
- Fsyncs per Tier A event (CAPACITY_ENVELOPE: fsync interval = 1)

CRITICAL INVARIANT: commit_index is assigned in exactly ONE place — this code. After implementation, verify with: rg -n 'commit_index' -t rust (should show assignment only here).

RESUME HANDLING:
- When opening existing EventLog, scan to find highest existing commit_index
- Next commit_index = highest + 1
- Ensures monotonicity even after restart

ERROR HANDLING:
- Serialized event line > 1,048,576 bytes (CAPACITY_ENVELOPE: EventLog max line bytes) → reject
- fsync failure → FM-APPEND-FAIL → must enter L5 safe failure posture (BACKPRESSURE_POLICY)
- Append stall > 250ms (CAPACITY_ENVELOPE: Append stall alarm ms) → alarm

DESIGN: EventLogWriter struct holding file handle + next commit_index. Pass explicitly, not a global singleton.

INVARIANTS: I1 (forensic truth), I5 (loud failure on FM-APPEND-FAIL).
CONSTITUTION: CAPACITY_ENVELOPE (fsync interval, max line bytes, stall alarm), BACKPRESSURE_POLICY (FM-APPEND-FAIL).
FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/eventlog.rs
close_reason: JSONL append writer: monotonic commit_index (sole assigner), fsync per Tier A, max line bytes rejection, resume from existing file. 7 tests pass.

title: M2.2: Content-addressed blob store (BLAKE3)
description:
Implement the content-addressed blob store for payloads exceeding the inline threshold.

CORE BEHAVIOR:
- Given payload bytes, compute BLAKE3 digest
- If digest already exists → return existing payload_ref (deduplication)
- Otherwise → write bytes to blob file, fsync, return payload_ref
- payload_ref = lowercase hex BLAKE3 digest of blob bytes as stored on disk
- Blob path format is implementation detail (e.g., blobs/{first2}/{digest})

THRESHOLDS (from CAPACITY_ENVELOPE):
- Inline payload max bytes: 16,384. Above this → blob store
- Max blob bytes: 50,000,000. Above this → exporter refuses (M8), but store still accepts
- Blob fsync timeout: 1,000ms. Beyond this → FM-BLOB-WRITE-FAIL

INTEGRATION WITH APPEND WRITER:
- Append writer checks if event payload exceeds inline threshold
- If so, calls blob store to write the payload
- Replaces inline payload with payload_ref in the event
- Then writes the event line to JSONL

ERROR HANDLING:
- Blob fsync fail/timeout → FM-BLOB-WRITE-FAIL (BACKPRESSURE_POLICY)
- Emit Error Tier A event if possible, then enter L5

IMPLEMENTATION:
- BLAKE3 crate for hashing (project standard — not SHA-256)
- Lowercase hex encoding for payload_ref
- Blob store directory adjacent to EventLog file
- No database needed — content-addressing = filename IS index

INVARIANTS: I1, I5.
FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/blob_store.rs
close_reason: Content-addressed blob store: BLAKE3 payload_ref, deduplication, atomic writes, prefix directories. 7 tests pass.

comments.author: yuan-cloud
comments.text: DEPENDENCY CHANGE: Blob store no longer depends on the writer. The blob store is a standalone component (give bytes, get BLAKE3 hash). The writer CALLS the blob store, not vice versa. M2.1 and M2.2 can now be developed in parallel. Writer tests (M2.4) depend on both.

title: M2.3: Clock skew detection
description:
Implement clock skew detection in the append writer path.

DETECTION LOGIC:
1. Track last seen timestamp_ns per source_id (HashMap<String, u64> in runtime state)
2. On each event: compare timestamp_ns with last seen for that source_id
3. If new timestamp < last seen AND delta > tolerance → emit ClockSkewDetected
4. Tolerance: 50,000,000 ns (50ms) from CAPACITY_ENVELOPE

ClockSkewDetected EVENT PAYLOAD:
- source_id: which source exhibited the skew
- expected_ns: last seen timestamp (monotonic expectation)
- actual_ns: the observed backward timestamp
- delta_ns: expected_ns - actual_ns (positive value)

ORDERING: ClockSkewDetected must be appended BEFORE the event that triggered it. This ensures the record shows "skew was detected, then the skewed event was recorded." Both events get their own commit_index.

DESIGN NOTES:
- timestamp_ns is metadata only (D6). We NEVER reorder based on it. Clock skew is surfaced, not corrected.
- Per-source tracking: different sources may have independent clocks. Track separately.
- Runtime state (source→last_timestamp map) is not persisted — rebuilt on EventLog replay if needed.
- The HashMap here is fine because it's runtime state, not serialized/hashed.

INVARIANTS: I1 (forensic truth — skew is recorded, not hidden), D6 (timestamp is metadata only).
CONSTITUTION: CAPACITY_ENVELOPE (clock skew tolerance ns = 50,000,000).
FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/eventlog.rs
close_reason: Clock skew detection: per-source timestamp tracking, tolerance 50ms, ClockSkewDetected emitted before triggering event, synthesized:true. 5 tests pass.

title: M2.4: Append writer monotonicity tests
description:
Write tests verifying the append writer correctly assigns monotonically increasing commit_index values.

REQUIRED TESTS:
1. Append 1000 events → verify commit_index is exactly 0..999, no gaps, no duplicates
2. Append to existing EventLog → verify commit_index continues from highest existing + 1
3. Verify commit_index is writer-assigned, not from input → create ImportEvent with no commit_index, verify CommittedEvent has writer-assigned value
4. EventLog max line bytes rejection → event that serializes > 1,048,576 bytes → rejected with error

TEST APPROACH:
- Use temp directories (tempfile crate or std::env::temp_dir)
- Write events, read back JSONL, parse and verify
- For the 1000-event test, verify the full sequence

EDGE CASES:
- Empty EventLog (first event gets index 0)
- Single event (index 0)
- Resume after simulated crash (open existing file, continue)
- Concurrent-safety: v0.1 is single-writer, but test that the writer doesn't silently allow double-init

FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/eventlog.rs (tests) or crates/vifei-core/tests/
close_reason: Append writer tests: 1000-event monotonicity, resume, start-at-zero, writer-assigned index, max line rejection, JSONL format, read roundtrip.

title: M2.5: Blob store tests
description:
Write tests for the content-addressed blob store.

REQUIRED TESTS:
1. Write event with payload above inline threshold (16,384 bytes) → verify blob file created and payload_ref resolves
2. Verify payload_ref is lowercase hex BLAKE3 digest of blob bytes
3. Deduplication: write same payload twice → same payload_ref, no duplicate blob file
4. Boundary: payload at exactly 16,384 bytes → inline. At 16,385 → blob.
5. Read back blob content → matches original payload bytes

TEST APPROACH:
- Use temp directories
- Create payloads of known size: vec![b'x'; 16_385] for above-threshold
- Compute expected BLAKE3 digest independently and compare with payload_ref
- Read back blob file and compare bytes

FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/blob_store.rs (tests) or crates/vifei-core/tests/
close_reason: Blob store tests: write+read, deduplication, BLAKE3 match, threshold boundary, nonexistent read, large blob, prefix dirs.

title: M2.6: Clock skew detection tests
description:
Write tests for clock skew detection.

REQUIRED TESTS:
1. Backward timestamp (delta > 50ms tolerance) → ClockSkewDetected emitted
2. Backward timestamp within tolerance (delta <= 50ms) → NO detection event
3. Boundary test: exactly at 50,000,000 ns tolerance (edge case)
4. Multiple sources: source A skews, source B normal → only A triggers detection
5. ClockSkewDetected event has correct fields: source_id, expected_ns, actual_ns, delta_ns

TEST APPROACH:
- Create events with controlled timestamp_ns values
- Append through the writer
- Read back EventLog, check for ClockSkewDetected events
- For boundary test: use tolerance ± 1 ns

FILES: crates/vifei-core/src/eventlog.rs (tests) or crates/vifei-core/tests/
close_reason: Clock skew tests: beyond tolerance, within tolerance, just-beyond boundary, multi-source independence, event field verification.

title: M6.1: TUI shell setup and main event loop
description:
Set up Ratatui framework, main event loop, EventLog loading, and CLI entry point.

COMPONENTS:
- CLI: vifei view <eventlog.jsonl> (via clap subcommand)
- Terminal init: raw mode, alternate screen (crossterm)
- Main event loop: poll key events → handle input → re-render
- EventLog loading: read JSONL → reduce → project → ViewModel
- Graceful shutdown: restore terminal state on exit or panic

MAIN LOOP STRUCTURE:
1. Load EventLog → reduce → project → initial ViewModel
2. Render initial frame
3. Loop: poll events → handle key input → re-project if needed → re-render
4. On quit signal, clean up terminal and exit

TECHNICAL STACK: Ratatui (Ratatui-compatible fork) for rendering, crossterm for terminal events, clap for CLI.

DESIGN NOTES:
- The TUI is read-only — it NEVER writes to the EventLog
- Keep rendering pure: ViewModel → terminal output, no side effects
- Ratatui supports snapshot testing via ftui-harness (used by M6.6)
- Consider std::panic::set_hook for terminal cleanup on panic

DEPENDENCIES: vifei-core (EventLog reading, reducer, projection).
FILES: crates/vifei-tui/src/lib.rs, crates/vifei-tui/src/main.rs

title: M6.3: Forensic Lens (timeline + inspector)

Implement the Forensic Lens — deep investigation view accessible via Tab toggle.

DISPLAY ELEMENTS:

  - ToolCall: tool name, arguments (or payload_ref link if blobbed)
  - ToolResult: tool name, result, status
  - PolicyDecision: from_level, to_level, trigger, queue_pressure
  - RedactionApplied: target event, field path, reason

- Enter: expand/collapse event details
- Events ordered by commit_index (NEVER by timestamp — D6)

SYNTHESIZED DISPLAY: Events with synthesized: true must have a visual marker (e.g., different color, [S] prefix, or icon) per BACKPRESSURE_POLICY projection invariants.

title: M6.4: Truth HUD strip
description:
Implement the Truth HUD — always-visible status strip confessing system truthfulness state.

REQUIRED FIELDS (BACKPRESSURE_POLICY projection invariants):
1. Current degradation ladder level (L0..L5)
2. Aggregation mode + bin size (e.g., "1:1", "10:1", "collapsed")
3. Backlog / queue pressure indicator
4. Tier A drops counter (must be 0)
5. Export safety state: UNKNOWN (until M8), CLEAN, DIRTY, REFUSED
6. Projection invariants version ("projection-invariants-v0.1")

THE TRUTH HUD IS THE MOST IMPORTANT UI ELEMENT. It is the system's confession about its own state. If it says "0 drops" and L0, the user can trust the display. If it shows L3 with pressure, the user knows the display is degraded.

VISIBILITY RULES:
- Always visible in BOTH lenses (Incident and Forensic)
- At L4 (Freeze UI), non-HUD panes may freeze, but Truth HUD remains live (BACKPRESSURE_POLICY)
- Single line or two-line strip at top or bottom of terminal

COLOR SUGGESTIONS:
- L0: green/default (healthy)
- L1-L3: yellow (degraded)
- L4-L5: red (critical)
- tier_a_drops > 0: red alert (should never happen)

FILES: crates/vifei-tui/src/ (truth_hud.rs)

title: M7: Tour stress harness v0.1
description:
Implement the Tour stress harness that ingests a large fixture through the full pipeline under simulated load and emits four proof artifacts for CI. Tour is how we prove that under stress, truth was not compromised — it is the testing backbone for invariants I2, I4, and I5.

KEY INVARIANTS: I2 (deterministic projection — proven via viewmodel.hash), I4 (testable determinism — proven via artifact stability), I5 (loud failure — proven via tier_a_drops == 0).
CONSTITUTION: CAPACITY_ENVELOPE (Large fixture = 10K events, throughput budgets), BACKPRESSURE_POLICY (ladder transitions, failure modes).
FILES: crates/vifei-tour/src/ plus fixtures and CI assertions.

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- vifei tour --stress emits to tour-output/: metrics.json, viewmodel.hash, ansi.capture, timetravel.capture
- metrics.json includes all required keys (projection_invariants_version, event_count_total, tier_a_drops, degradation levels/transitions, queue_pressure, export_safety_state)
- CI assertions: tier_a_drops == 0, degradation transitions respect ladder order, viewmodel.hash stable on re-run, PolicyDecision events match metrics.json transitions
- Stress fixture meets 10K events target

DEPENDS ON: M5 (projection) and M6 (TUI shell — for ansi.capture). BLOCKS: nothing (terminal milestone on the M4→M5→M6→M7 chain).

title: M7.1: Tour CLI subcommand with --stress
description:
Implement the Tour CLI subcommand: vifei tour --stress <fixture.jsonl>

Tour is a deterministic stress harness — NOT a benchmark. It proves that under stress, truth was not compromised.

PIPELINE:
1. Import fixture through full pipeline (parser → append writer)
2. Reduce the full EventLog
3. Project with stress-configured ProjectionInvariants
4. Emit 4 proof artifacts to tour-output/ directory

CLI INTERFACE:
- vifei tour --stress <fixture.jsonl>
- --output-dir <path> (default: tour-output/)
- Command must be deterministic: same fixture → same artifacts

DETERMINISM: The Tour harness itself must not introduce nondeterminism. No random seeds, no wall-clock-dependent behavior, no platform-dependent formatting. Same fixture → identical artifacts, always.

description:
Implement CI-runnable tests asserting Tour invariants on proof artifacts.

2. degradation_transitions respect ladder order (no level skipping except L5 on fatal)

title: M8: Share-safe export v0.1
description:
Implement share-safe export with deterministic bundling, secret scanning, and refusal reporting. Export is the gate between internal truth and external sharing — it must be conservative and refuse by default when secrets are detected.

KEY INVARIANTS: I3 (share-safe export — refuses when secrets remain, emits refusal report), I4 (testable determinism — bundle_hash stability), I5 (loud failure — refusal is explicit, not silent).
CONSTITUTION: CAPACITY_ENVELOPE (Export determinism targets: PAX tar, zstd level 3, normalized metadata).
FILES: crates/vifei-export/src/ plus tests.

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- vifei export --share-safe -o bundle.tar.zst produces deterministic archive (same inputs → same bundle_hash)
- Deterministic bundling: sorted entries, normalized metadata (mtime=0, uid/gid=0), PAX tar, zstd level 3
- Secret scanner checks event payloads and blob contents
- If secrets: refuse + emit refusal-report.json with event_id, field_path, matched_pattern, blob_ref
- If clean: bundle with embedded integrity manifest
- Tests: clean export hash stability, secret refusal, re-export hash match

DEPENDS ON: M2 (append writer — for EventLog reading and blob store). BLOCKS: nothing (independent chain from M2).
close_reason: done

title: M8.1: Export CLI subcommand and pipeline
description:
Implement export CLI subcommand and pipeline orchestration.

CLI: vifei export --share-safe -o bundle.tar.zst <eventlog.jsonl>

PIPELINE:
1. Read EventLog and discover associated blobs
2. Run secret scanner on all event payloads and blob contents (M8.2)
3. If secrets detected → refuse export, emit refusal-report.json (M8.3)
4. If clean → build deterministic archive with integrity manifest (M8.4, M8.5)

FLAGS:
- --share-safe: enables secret scanning (mandatory in v0.1, refuse without it)
- -o <path>: output bundle path
- Input: EventLog JSONL path

DESIGN: Export is the gate between internal truth and external sharing. Conservative by default — refuse if ANY doubt about safety.

INVARIANTS: I3 (share-safe export).
FILES: crates/vifei-export/src/
close_reason: done

title: M8.2: Secret scanner (pattern matching)
description:
Implement secret scanner for event payloads and blob contents.

SCANNER BEHAVIOR:
- Scan all event payload fields (inline text)
- Scan all blob contents referenced by payload_ref
- Check against configurable pattern set (regex or literal)

MINIMUM v0.1 PATTERNS:
- API keys: AWS (AKIA...), OpenAI (sk-...), Anthropic (sk-ant-...), generic API key formats
- Tokens: JWT (eyJ...), Bearer tokens, OAuth tokens
- Secrets: password=, secret=, api_key=, private_key, BEGIN RSA/EC PRIVATE KEY
- PII: email addresses (basic), phone numbers (basic)

SCANNER OUTPUT:
- Per match: event_id, field_path (dot-delimited), matched_pattern name, blob_ref (if in blob)
- Feeds into refusal report (M8.3)

DESIGN NOTES:
- v0.1 is content-based only (regex/pattern matching), not metadata-based
- Pattern set defined as configurable list, not hardcoded in scanner logic
- Handle both UTF-8 text and binary blob content
- Err on side of more patterns (false positives safer than false negatives for security)

PRE-M0 RISK NOTE: "The secret scanner pattern set is still undefined — M8 implementer must make judgment calls about what patterns to check."

INVARIANTS: I3 (share-safe export).
FILES: crates/vifei-export/src/
close_reason: done

title: M8.3: Refusal report generation
description:
Implement refusal report generation when secrets are detected.

SCHEMA (PLANS.md Artifact schema contracts):
{
  "report_version": "refusal-v0.1",
  "eventlog_path": "<path>",
  "blocked_items": [
    {
      "event_id": "<id>",
      "field_path": "payload.api_key",
      "matched_pattern": "<pattern name or regex>",
      "blob_ref": "<optional, if secret in blob>"
    }
  ],
  "scan_timestamp_utc": "<ISO 8601>",
  "scanner_version": "<version>"
}

REQUIREMENTS:
- blocked_items must be stably sorted (deterministic order for auditability)
- Report must explain EXACTLY what blocked export — no vague "secrets detected" messages
- Same scan inputs → same report (deterministic artifact)
- scan_timestamp_utc is informational only (not in hash if report is hashed)

INVARIANTS: I3 (share-safe export — explicit refusal), I5 (loud failure — refusal is never silent).
FILES: crates/vifei-export/src/
close_reason: Refusal report schema matches PLANS.md contract. Blocked items stably sorted. 4 new tests (schema conformance, deterministic ordering, blob_ref presence/absence). All 219 tests pass.

title: M8.4: Deterministic tar+zstd bundling
description:
Implement deterministic archive creation for clean exports.

DETERMINISM REQUIREMENTS (CAPACITY_ENVELOPE Export determinism targets):
- Tar format: POSIX (PAX)
- Zstd compression level: 3
- Tar mtime: 0 (Unix epoch, all entries normalized)
- Tar uid/gid: 0 (root, normalized)
- Tar username/groupname: empty
- PAX extended headers: minimal (only size and path)

ARCHIVE ENTRY ORDERING:
- Entries sorted deterministically (alphabetical by path)
- Same entries → same order → same bytes

ARCHIVE CONTENTS:
- EventLog JSONL file
- All referenced blobs
- Integrity manifest (M8.5)
- Bundle metadata (version, creation parameters)

IMPLEMENTATION:
- tar crate for PAX tar creation
- zstd crate with level=3
- Pin crate versions in Cargo.lock (Pre-M0 risk: version-dependent PAX behavior)
- Normalize ALL metadata — any machine-specific value breaks determinism
- bundle_hash = BLAKE3 of final .tar.zst bytes

CONSTITUTION: CAPACITY_ENVELOPE (Export determinism targets).
FILES: crates/vifei-export/src/
close_reason: Acceptance criteria met: deterministic tar+zstd bundling with normalized metadata, sorted entries, BLAKE3 hash, 5 tests passing

title: M8.5: Integrity manifest for clean bundles
description:
Implement integrity manifest embedded in clean export bundles.

MANIFEST CONTENTS:
- File list: all files in bundle with BLAKE3 digests
- bundle_hash: BLAKE3 of overall archive
- EventLog commit_index range (first, last)
- projection_invariants_version (context)

FORMAT:
- JSON file included as tar entry (e.g., manifest.json)
- Stably sorted entries for determinism
- All hashes lowercase hex

The manifest is the "receipt" for bundle consumers — tells them exactly what's inside and how to verify it.

FILES: crates/vifei-export/src/
close_reason: Acceptance criteria met: integrity manifest with file BLAKE3 digests, commit_index range, projection_invariants_version, 5 tests passing

title: M3: Agent Cassette importer v0.1
description:
Implement the Agent Cassette JSONL importer — the first (and only v0.1) supported ingestion path. Maps external session recordings into Vifei's event schema, preserving source order exactly as received, and marking any synthesized fields.

KEY INVARIANTS: I1 (forensic truth — correct recording), D2 (Tier A minimal set), D6 (no timestamp sorting).
CONSTITUTION: Referenced via event types and append writer contracts.
FILES: crates/vifei-import/src/cassette.rs plus fixtures and tests.

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
- Reads Agent Cassette JSONL, maps events to Vifei event schema
- Does NOT sort by timestamp — preserves source order exactly
- Synthesized/inferred fields marked with synthesized: true
- At least one real session fixture in fixtures/ with provenance README
- Integration test: import fixture, verify Tier A present and commit_index monotonic

DEPENDS ON: M2 (append writer API). BLOCKS: nothing directly (end of the M0→M1→M2→M3 chain).
close_reason: M3 complete: Agent Cassette importer with streaming parser, 5-type event mapping, synthesized marking, test fixture with provenance, 3 integration tests. 22 tests total (19 unit + 3 integration). Quality gates: fmt ✓, clippy ✓, 75 tests ✓. UBS: 0 critical. Risk assessment appended.

comments.author: yuan-cloud
comments.text: DEPENDENCY CHANGE: M3 now depends on M1 (not M2). The parser (M3.1-M3.3) produces ImportEvents using M1 event types — it does not need the append writer. Only M3.5 (integration test) needs M2.1 (writer) to test the full import pipeline. This unlocks M3 parser work to start in parallel with M2.

title: M3.1: Agent Cassette JSONL format parser
description:
Implement a streaming parser for Agent Cassette JSONL format — the first and only v0.1 ingestion path.

PARSER REQUIREMENTS:
- Read line-by-line from JSONL file or stream (streaming, not load-all-at-once)
- Parse each line as JSON
- Map recognized record types to Vifei event types (see M3.2)
- Handle unknown record types gracefully: map to Generic event with tier B/C
- Report parse errors with line number for debugging

ERROR HANDLING:
- Malformed JSON line → emit Error event with line number context, continue parsing
- Unknown record type → map to Generic event variant
- Missing required fields → synthesize where possible, mark synthesized: true (see M3.3)

CRITICAL CONSTRAINT: The parser returns an iterator of ImportEvent values. It must NOT sort, deduplicate, or reorder events in any way. Source order is preserved exactly. The append writer assigns commit_index. The importer never re-sorts, deduplicates, or "fixes history" based on timestamps — out-of-order timestamps are surfaced via ClockSkewDetected, not corrected (PLANS.md D6, M3 acceptance criteria).

FILES: crates/vifei-import/src/cassette.rs
close_reason: Agent Cassette JSONL parser implemented: parse_cassette() streaming parser, map_record(), map_payload(), parse_iso8601_ns(). 19 unit tests pass.

comments.author: yuan-cloud
comments.text: DEPENDENCY CHANGE: Parser now depends on M1.3 (event types), not M2.1 (writer). The parser produces ImportEvents — it only needs the event type definitions to construct them. The writer is consumed by M3.5 (integration test), not the parser itself.

title: M3.2: Event type mapping (Cassette → Vifei)
description:
Define the mapping from Agent Cassette record types to Vifei event types.

MAPPING TARGETS:
- Agent run start → RunStart
- Agent run end → RunEnd
- Tool invocation → ToolCall
- Tool response → ToolResult
- Policy/safety decisions → PolicyDecision (if present in Cassette format)
- Errors → Error
- All other types → Generic with appropriate tier

MAPPING PRINCIPLES:
1. Preserve source order exactly as received (NEVER re-sort by timestamp)
2. Map to the most specific Tier A type when possible
3. Fall back to Generic for unrecognized types
4. Set tier appropriately (A for core events, B/C for auxiliary)
5. Set synthesized: true for any field inferred by the mapping (see M3.3)

FIELD MAPPING:
- run_id: from Cassette session ID, or synthesized
- event_id: from Cassette event ID, or synthesized as "{source_id}:{source_seq}"
- source_id: identifies the Cassette source (e.g., "agent-cassette")
- source_seq: monotonic per source if available, else synthesized
- timestamp_ns: from Cassette timestamp, converted to nanoseconds
- Large payloads: will be blobbed by the append writer (not the importer's concern)

This mapping is the bridge between external format and internal truth. The forensic chain (I1) depends on correct, honest mapping.

FILES: crates/vifei-import/src/cassette.rs
close_reason: Event type mapping: session_start→RunStart, session_end→RunEnd, tool_use→ToolCall, tool_result→ToolResult, error→Error, unknown→Generic(Tier B). Tested.

title: M3.3: Synthesized field detection and marking
description:
Implement logic to detect and mark synthesized (inferred/invented) fields.

RULE (PLANS.md D2): "Do not invent meaning. If any field is synthesized or inferred, mark it explicitly as synthesized: true and surface the marker in UI."

FIELDS THAT MAY NEED SYNTHESIS:
- event_id: if Cassette provides no unique ID → synthesize as "{source_id}:{source_seq}"
- source_seq: if Cassette provides no sequence number → synthesize monotonically
- run_id: if not explicitly present in Cassette format
- tier: if Cassette doesn't classify event importance

RULES:
- If ANY field on the event is synthesized, the event-level synthesized flag = true
- The synthesized flag is on ImportEvent wrapper, not per-field in v0.1
- Document which fields are synthesized for each mapping case (inline comments or module docs)

DOWNSTREAM IMPACTS:
- Reducer (M4): processes synthesized events identically (flag is metadata, not processing directive)
- Projection (M5): MUST visually distinguish synthesized events in Forensic Lens (BACKPRESSURE_POLICY projection invariant)
- Export (M8): preserves synthesized marker in bundles

FILES: crates/vifei-import/src/cassette.rs
close_reason: All cassette events marked synthesized=true (source_seq always synthesized). Event IDs from source id field when present, else synthesized as cassette:{seq}. Tested.

This fixture is used by M3.5 (integration tests) and may serve as smoke test input for M4-M7.

title: M3.5: Importer integration tests
description:
Write integration tests: import fixture through full pipeline (parser → append writer) and verify output.

REQUIRED ASSERTIONS:
1. Import fixture → read back EventLog → Tier A events present
2. commit_index is monotonically increasing (0, 1, 2, ...)
3. Source order preserved (events appear in same order as fixture)
4. No timestamp-based reordering occurred
5. Synthesized fields properly marked

TEST APPROACH:
- Use fixture from M3.4
- Run through real cassette parser and append writer
- Read back JSONL EventLog, parse, verify

EDGE CASES:
- Empty fixture (no events)
- Fixture with one event
- Fixture with events from multiple sources

INVARIANTS VERIFIED: I1 (forensic truth), D6 (commit_index ordering).
FILES: crates/vifei-import/tests/
